column4: why does my ethernet card seem to have 2 mac addresses, leading to my router not assigning the static ip sometimes?
have you got two ethernet cards?
it's a laptop so it has a wireless and an ethernet. it shouldn't have "two ethernet cards" to my knowledge..
the wireless card is considered to be a network card
lol i get that. but i'm not on wireless, it's switched off. just on ethernet
open terminal and type sudo ifconfig
it sounds like you are filtering by mac address
no because once i unplug the ethernet c0rd and replug, it will assign the static ip since the ifconfig displays a diff mac address. wats going on...
your mac address is fixed as it's built into the card
as you have two network interfaces, you need to allow both mac addresses into your router
when i unplug/replug the cord, the mac address in eth0 changes to the one i've assigned a static ip in the router
what happens if its plugged in and you do a cold boot
it gets set to that aa:00:04:00:0a:04 address which i haven't assigned a static ip for
have you checked your configs in /etc
i'm asking
have you checked your configs in /etc
sorry, was trying to see what these configs are lol. ummm i have not. wat do u want me to check?
have you set a static ip address?
i've set the static ip address in my router, assigning the mac address which only comes up after unplug/replug
i guess i could assign both mac addresses to the same ip (if the router lets me), but i'm just curious why it's even doing this in the first place...
PM'd you
